text: but being
gay has opened me helps me understand
how one can be
misunderstood how you can be
trapped in the lens of somebody else's
stereotype whether it's all kids are
like that or all teenage boys are like
that or all gay people are like that and
it's made me I think more compassionate
not necessarily any less um strict with
my sons but certainly more understanding
I think of the
challenges they are
facing and um and really the challenges
that I as a parent am facing to make
sure we grow them into fine young men
and you know teenage boys are you know
it's day by day on that
score my younger son tried out for the
local baseball team we moved recently a
couple years ago now from Cambridge
which is when I was in the legislature
where I served uh to Jamaica plane
Massachusetts and I lived in a part of
Jamaica plane that was where a lot of
Dominicans lived a lot of Dominican
folks lived and a lot of lesbians so we
had the best Little League team in the
city it was the place everybody wanted
to come and the uh tryouts happened my
son made the team he was thrilled the
second day of practice comes home
excited third day of practice comes home
and he's in
tears and I asked Nathaniel what's
what's the problem and he wouldn't
didn't want to talk to me about it you
know 13 He you know he's a tough kid
he's not going to let anything uh let me
see any vulnerability or weakness so I
called this coach and his coach
explained you know I was going to call
you
Jarrett
the baseball team were they were
practicing today there were a couple of
other kids that Nathaniel was trying to
make friends with and they were calling
each other gay and
Nathaniel in the attempt to make friends
offered up that his two dads were gay
not understanding that they were using
the term gay in a way that was
derogatory making fun of each other and
so when he offered that up they clearly
ate that up and began to ridicule him
which totally um hurt
disoriented uh defeated him in his
intentions in his new you know new
neighborhood new community new team to
be a valued member and embrace bed
member of his baseball team and that was
very hard it was hard because you know
we live in Massachusetts we live in a
place where we're nearly legally equal
but there's no court and there's no
legislature that can change how
Nathaniel was treated on the baseball
diamond you know it's wonderful living
in Massachusetts because we are uh we
have the option of full equality of
legal equality and that's it's important
to distinguish between legal equality
the state St level and full legal
equality which would include Federal
recognition of our marriage of our
family which isn't the case because of
the federal Defense of Marriage Act but
at the state level for sure we are about
as equal in Massachusetts as anywhere
else in the United States as a gay
family and what does that mean well it
means that you know I am as it is
um I have the same um challenges and
frustrations raising kids but I also
have the same rights uh that are
necessary for me to be able to take care
of my kids whether it's access to school
records whether it's being able to get
the hospital uh to take care of them if
my husband's name is first on the list
I'll still be recognized because we are
legally married uh if I were to die we
wouldn't face additional state tax
burdens because our relationship isn't
recognized countless ways six 700
different ways we are held to be equal
in Massachusetts that I wouldn't be in
another state and that's very
important
